speakers.name: Speaker 1
speakers.transcript: Good morning everyone. Thanks for joining the Q4 planning sync. I want to cover three things today: the customer migration timeline, the API versioning strategy, and our infrastructure budget for next year. Sarah, can you start us off with an update on the migration? Last I heard we had about two hundred customers still on the legacy platform.

speakers.name: Speaker 2
speakers.transcript: Sure thing. So we've actually made good progress since last week. We're now down to one hundred and forty seven customers on the legacy system. The biggest blocker has been the Acme Corporation account. They have some custom integrations with our old REST API that don't translate cleanly to GraphQL. I've scheduled a call with their engineering team for Thursday, December twelfth, to walk through the migration path. Assuming that goes well, I think we can hit our January fifteenth deadline.

speakers.name: Speaker 3
speakers.transcript: That's helpful context. On the API versioning side, I want to propose we adopt semantic versioning starting with version two point zero. The current approach of date-based versions like twenty twenty three dash eleven is causing confusion with our enterprise clients. They keep asking which version is newer. I've drafted an RFC and shared it in the engineering Slack channel. The main trade-off is that we'd need to maintain backwards compatibility for at least eighteen months per major version, which means more testing overhead. But I think the developer experience improvement is worth it. Can everyone review the RFC by end of week and add comments?

combined_transcript: Good morning everyone. Thanks for joining the Q4 planning sync. I want to cover three things today: the customer migration timeline, the API versioning strategy, and our infrastructure budget for next year. Sarah, can you start us off with an update on the migration? Last I heard we had about two hundred customers still on the legacy platform. Sure thing. So we've actually made good progress since last week. We're now down to one hundred and forty seven customers on the legacy system. The biggest blocker has been the Acme Corporation account. They have some custom integrations with our old REST API that don't translate cleanly to GraphQL. I've scheduled a call with their engineering team for Thursday, December twelfth, to walk through the migration path. Assuming that goes well, I think we can hit our January fifteenth deadline. That's helpful context. On the API versioning side, I want to propose we adopt semantic versioning starting with version two point zero. The current approach of date-based versions like twenty twenty three dash eleven is causing confusion with our enterprise clients. They keep asking which version is newer. I've drafted an RFC and shared it in the engineering Slack channel. The main trade-off is that we'd need to maintain backwards compatibility for at least eighteen months per major version, which means more testing overhead. But I think the developer experience improvement is worth it. Can everyone review the RFC by end of week and add comments?
